channel.title: Combined Politepol Feed
channel.description: Merged feed from multiple Politepol sources

item.title: Spanish court conditionally releases PM's former ally from jail
item.description: Spain's Supreme Court ordered on Wednesday the provisional release from jail of a former senior official within the ruling Socialist Party, citing reduced risk of evidence tampering amid an ongoing corruption investigation. Santos Cerdan, who had been remanded in custody since June, faces potentia

item.title: Ten killed and 40 wounded in heavy Russian attack on Ukraine, officials say
item.description: Ten people were killed in a heavy overnight Russian missile and drone attack that struck a residential tower block in the western Ukrainian city of Ternopil, Ukrainian officials said on Wednesday. Another 40 people were wounded in the overnight strikes on Ukraine that targeted energy and transport

item.title: Zelenskiy says Kyiv ready for peace talks, but will not cede territory
item.description:
Ukraine is ready for peace talks but will not withdraw its troops from additional territory first as Moscow has demanded, President Volodymyr Zelenskiy said.
In comments to reporters released on Tuesday, he said he was happy for talks to be held anywhere, except in Russia itself or on the

item.title: Left-wing Connolly set to win Irish presidency as opponents concede
item.description: Catherine Connolly, a veteran lawmaker on the far-left of the Irish political spectrum, was set to be elected the country's next president on Saturday as members of the governing parties conceded defeat. Early tallies of votes after counting began at 0800 GMT showed a wide lead for Connolly, 68, a

item.title: King Charles and Pope Leo pray together in a 500-year first
item.description: Britain’s King Charles and Pope Leo prayed together in the Vatican’s Sistine Chapel on Thursday, in the first joint worship including an English monarch and a Catholic pontiff since King Henry VIII broke away from Rome in 1534. Latin chants and English prayers echoed through the chapel

item.title: Portuguese parliament approves bill banning face coverings in publicq
item.description: Portugal 's parliament on Friday approved a bill banning face veils worn for “gender or religious” reasons in public, in a move seen as targeting the face coverings worn by some Muslim women. The measure was proposed by the far-right Chega party and would prohibit coverings such as bur

item.title: Vatican visit by King Charles to show closening Anglican-Catholic ties
item.description: Britain's King Charles and Queen Camilla will meet Pope Leo at the Vatican next week in a visit seen as a sign of closening ties between the Catholic Church and the Anglican Communion, five centuries after their turbulent separation. The British royals will arrive on Oct 22 for the two-day state v

item.title: EU proposes 'flagship' defence projects to counter drones, protect eastern border
item.description: The European Commission on Thursday proposed four European flagship defence projects - including a counter-drone system and a plan to fortify the eastern border - as part of a drive to get the continent ready to defend itself by 2030. The proposals, in a defence policy "roadmap", reflect fears fue

item.title: Italy's historically poor south sees brighter future as workers return
item.description: For decades, the story of southern Italy has been one of departure, of generations leaving the hills of Calabria and the shores of Sicily in search of opportunity in the industrial north or abroad. Now however, growing numbers of migrants are being lured back by improving job prospects and infrast

item.title: At least 20 injured after two trains collide in Slovakia
item.description: Two trains collided in eastern Slovakia on Monday, derailing an engine and a carriage and injuring at least 20 people, emergency services and local media reported. Police footage posted on Facebook showed mangled wreckage, and a locomotive and a carriage that had come off the tracks lying on the s

item.title: France's Macron won't resign, as no-confidence votes threaten his new government
item.description: French President Emmanuel Macron rejected calls to resign and blasted his opponents on Monday, as his latest government was threatened by two no-confidence motions that could bring it down by the end of the week. France is in the midst of its worst political crisis in decades as a succession of mi

item.title: UK's Reeves plans to build bigger budget buffer - Telegraph
item.description: British finance minister Rachel Reeves plans to build up a bigger buffer against her main fiscal rule at next month's budget in an effort to better insulate government finances from future shocks, the Sunday Telegraph reported. Reeves said in her March spring statement that her spending and tax pl

item.title: Saudi crown prince heads to a friendlier US Congress
item.description: Lawmakers are set to meet with Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman at the US Capitol on Wednesday on the second day of a visit to the United States that has aimed to tout stronger-than-ever economic and security ties with Washington while brushing off scrutiny of his human rights record. Presid

item.title: UK pay settlements rise to highest in 2025, Brightmine says
item.description: Median pay settlements granted by British employers in the three months to the end of October rose to their highest so far this year at 3.3%, up from 3.1% in the three months to September. Brightmine said the move reflected higher public sector pay deals which took effect in August and September.

item.title: US judge to weigh Trump's influence over case against ex-FBI chief Comey
item.description: Lawyers for former FBI Director James Comey will renew their attempts to get a criminal case against him tossed out on Wednesday, arguing that President Donald Trump's personal animosity improperly motivated the prosecution. The hearing before U.S. District Judge Michael Nachmanoff in Alexandria,

item.title: China bans Japanese seafood as diplomatic dispute deepens
item.description: China informed Japan on Wednesday that it will ban all imports of Japanese seafood, media outlets reported - a decision which comes amid an escalating diplomatic dispute between Asia's top two economies. Tensions between the two countries ignited after new Japanese Prime Minister Sanae Takaichi sa

item.title: Trump says Cambodia, Thailand going to be fine after calls over conflict
President Trump signs government funding bill, ending shutdown after a record 43-day disruption
37 killed in Peru road crash
Trump says no US government official will attend G20 summit in South Africa
US judge rules Trump illegally ordered National Guard to Portland, Oregon
Iranian plot to kill Israel's ambassador to Mexico contained, US official says
Mamdani to Trump: 'Turn the volume up'
Trump tells Ilhan Omar to leave US
Fire at Mexico store kills at least 23
Trump sets refugee ceiling at record-low 7,500 with focus on white South Africans
Taiwan does not want China's 'one country, two systems', president says
Hurricane Melissa death toll climbs to 44
Israeli military strikes southern Lebanon after evacuation warning
item.description: The Israeli military carried out powerful airstrikes in two villages in southern Lebanon on Wednesday, witnesses said, pressing a campaign of near-daily attacks in the border region where Israel says it is targeting Iran-backed Hezbollah. The Israeli military said it was striking "several Hezbolla

item.title: Air India lobbies to use airspace over China's Xinjiang as financial woes mount
item.description: Air India is lobbying the Indian government to convince China to let it use a sensitive military airspace zone in Xinjiang to shorten routes as the financial toll from a ban on Indian carriers flying over Pakistan mounts, a company document shows. The unusual request comes just weeks after direct

item.title: Indonesian teen's diary and online trail reveal path to Jakarta mosque blasts
item.description: An Indonesian student suspected of carrying out a bomb attack at his school mosque in Jakarta wrote of feeling isolated in his 42-page diary and drew inspiration from a Telegram group glorifying white supremacist attacks, according to new details from police. The early‑November explosions struck w

item.title: Myanmar refugees join Thai workforce
item.description: Tun Min Lat climbs a bamboo ladder in the longan orchards of eastern Thailand, moving from tree to tree as he plucks the juicy tropical fruit in the sweltering heat of a November morning. For the first time in the nearly two decades he has lived in Thailand, the 42-year-old Myanmar refugee is able

item.title: Indonesia landslide kills 6 in Central Java, 17 missing, state media says
item.description: A landslide in Indonesia's Central Java killed six people with 17 missing, state news agency Antara reported on Saturday, after prolonged, heavy rains. The landslide on Thursday in the city of Cilacap buried a dozen houses in Cibeunying village, Antara said, citing disaster official Budi Irawan.

item.title: Two dead, 18 hurt in South Korea after truck crashes into market, media reports say
item.description: A light truck crashed into a market in South Korea on Thursday, ploughing 150 metres (164 yards) along a passageway lined with stalls before coming to a halt, killing two people and injuring 18, according to emergency officials and media reports. The incident took place at a market located in Buch

item.title: Australian state signs country's first treaty with Indigenous people into law
item.description: The Australian state of Victoria on Thursday signed into law the country’s first treaty with Indigenous people, hailed by advocates as a major step towards reconciliation by giving first inhabitants more oversight on decisions that concern them. The treaty, which will take effect on Dec 12,

item.title: Afghanistan economic recovery buckles as nine in 10 families go hungry or into debt, UNDP says
item.description: Afghanistan's economic recovery is buckling as nine in 10 households are forced to skip meals, sell belongings or take on debt to survive, the United Nations said on Wednesday, warning that mass returns are exacerbating the country's worst crisis since the Taliban returned to power. A United Natio

item.title: Pakistan blames India after suicide bomber kills 12 in Islamabad
item.description: Pakistan has accused India of orchestrating a deadly suicide blast that killed at least 12 people and injured more than 30 outside a district court in Islamabad on Tuesday, intensifying regional tensions as officials also pointed fingers at Afghan-based militants. According to Interior Minister Mo

item.title: India's Modi vows not to spare those behind Delhi car blast
item.description: Indian police are investigating a deadly car blast in the capital under a law used to fight "terrorism", an officer said on Tuesday, as Prime Minister Narendra Modi vowed to bring to justice all those responsible. The explosion near the historic Red Fort on Monday evening killed at least eight peo

item.title: Pakistan's army chief to get expanded powers under proposed reform
item.description: Pakistan's powerful army chief will be given an expanded role and the remit of the Supreme Court will be curbed under constitutional changes passed by the upper house of parliament on Monday, a move the opposition says will undermine democracy. Pakistan, historically coup-prone, is seeing its long

item.title: Indonesia grants national hero status to late strongman President Suharto
item.description: Indonesia awarded the title of national hero on Monday to late President Suharto, who was forced out of office in 1998 by violent protests that ended a three-decade rule marred by accusations of mass human rights violations, corruption and nepotism. The title was conferred in a ceremony presided o
